abstract_sentences.1: Implicit discourse relation classification is of great challenge due to the lack of connectives as strong linguistic cues, which motivates the use of annotated implicit connectives to improve the recognition.
abstract_sentences.2: We propose a feature imitation framework in which an implicit relation network is driven to learn from another neural network with access to connectives, and thus encouraged to extract similarly salient features for accurate classification.
abstract_sentences.3: We develop an adversarial model to enable an adaptive imitation scheme through competition between the implicit network and a rival feature discriminator.
abstract_sentences.4: Our method effectively transfers discriminability of connectives to the implicit features, and achieves state-of-the-art performance on the PDTB benchmark.

body_sentences.14: Connectives (e.g., but, so, etc) are one of the most critical linguistic cues for identifying discourse relations.
body_sentences.15: When explicit connectives are present in the text, a simple frequency-based mapping is sufficient to achieve over 85% classification accuracy (Xue et al., 2016; Li et al., 2016).
body_sentences.16: In contrast, implicit discourse relation recognition has long been seen as a challenging problem, with the best accuracy so far still lower than 50% (Chen et al., 2015).
body_sentences.17: In the implicit case, discourse relations are not lexicalized by connectives, but to be inferred from relevant sentences (i.e., arguments).
body_sentences.18: For example, the following two adjacent sentences Arg1 and Arg2 imply relation Cause (i.e., Arg2 is the cause of Arg1).
body_sentences.21:
[Implicit connective]: Because
[Discourse relation]: Cause
Various attempts have been made to directly infer underlying relations by modeling the semantics of the arguments, ranging from feature-based methods (Lin et al., 2009; Pitler et al., 2009) to the very recent end-to-end neural models (Chen et al., 2016a; Qin et al., 2016c).
body_sentences.22: Despite impressive performance, the absence of strong explicit connective cues has made the inference extremely hard and hindered further improvement.
body_sentences.23: In fact, even the human annotators would make use of connectives to aid relation annotation.
body_sentences.24: For instance, the popular Penn Discourse Treebank (PDTB) benchmark data (Prasad et al., 2008) was annotated by first inserting a connective expression (i.e., implicit connective, as shown in the above example) manually, and determining the abstract relation by combining both the implicit connective and contextual semantics.

body_sentences.33: In this paper, we propose a novel neural method that incorporates implicit connectives in a principled adversarial framework.
body_sentences.34: We use deep neural models for relation classification, and take the intuition that, sentence arguments integrated with connectives would enable highly discriminative neural features for accurate relation inference, and an ideal implicit relation classifier, even though without access to connectives, should mimic the connective-augmented reasoning behavior by extracting similarly salient features.
body_sentences.35: We therefore setup a secondary network in addition to the implicit relation classifier, building upon connectiveaugmented inputs and serving as a feature learning model for the implicit classifier to emulate.

body_sentences.52: 2 Related Work    2.1 Implicit Discourse Relation Recognition  There has been a surge of interest in implicit discourse parsing since the release of PDTB (Prasad et al., 2008), the first large discourse corpus distinguishing implicit examples from explicit ones.

body_sentences.77: 3 Adversarial Method  Discourse connectives are key indicators for discourse relation.
body_sentences.78: In the annotation procedure of the PDTB implicit relation benchmark, annotators inserted implicit connective expressions between adjacent sentences to lexicalize abstract relations and help with final decisions.
body_sentences.79: Our model aims at making full use of the provided implicit connectives at training time to regulate learning of implicit relation recognizer, encouraging extraction of highly discriminative semantics from raw arguments, and improving generalization at test time.
body_sentences.80: Our method provides a novel adversarial framework that leverages connective information in a flexible adaptive manner, and is efficiently trained end-to-end through standard back-propagation.
body_sentences.81: The basic idea of the proposed approach is simple.
body_sentences.82: We want our implicit relation recognizer, which predicts the underlying relation of sentence arguments without discourse connective, to have prediction behaviors close to a connectiveaugmented relation recognizer which is provided with a discourse connective in addition to the arguments.
body_sentences.83: The connective-augmented recognizer is in analogy to an annotator with the help of connectives as in the human annotation process, and the implicit recognizer would be improved by learning from such an “informed” annotator.
body_sentences.84: Specifically, we want the latent features extracted by the two models to match as closely as possible, which explicitly transfers the discriminability of the connective-augmented representations to implicit ones.
body_sentences.85: To this end, instead of manually selecting a closeness metric, we take advantage of the adversarial framework by constructing a two-player zero-sum game between the implicit recognizer and a rival discriminator.
body_sentences.86: The discriminator attempts to distinguish between the features extracted by the two relation models, while the implicit relation model is trained to maximize the accuracy on implicit data, and at the same time to confuse the discriminator.
body_sentences.87: In the next we first present the overall architecture of the proposed approach (section 3.1), then develop the training procedure (section 3.2).

body_sentences.89: 3.1 Model Architecture  Let (x, y) be a pair of input and output of implicit relation classification, where x = (x1,x2) is a pair of sentence arguments, and y is the underlying discourse relation.
body_sentences.90: Each training example also includes an annotated implicit connective c that best expresses the relation.
body_sentences.91: Figure 1 shows the architecture of our framework.
body_sentences.92: The neural model for implicit relation classification (i-CNN in the figure) extracts latent representation from the arguments, denoted as HI(x1,x2), and feeds the feature into a classifier C for final prediction C(HI(x1,x2)).
body_sentences.93: For ease of notation, we will also use HI(x) to denote the latent feature on data x.
body_sentences.94: The second relation network (a-CNN) takes as inputs the sentence arguments along with an implicit connective, to induce the connectiveaugmented representation HA(x1,x2, c), and obtains relation prediction C(HA(x1,x2, c)).
body_sentences.95: Note that the same final classifierC is used for both networks, so that the feature representations by the two networks are ensured to be within the same semantic space, enabling feature emulation as presented shortly.
body_sentences.96: We further pair the implicit network with a rival discriminator D to form our adversarial game.
body_sentences.97: The discriminator is to differentiate between the reasoning behaviors of the implicit network i-CNN and the augmented network a-CNN.

Specifically, D is a binary classifier that takes as inputs a la-
tent feature H derived from either i-CNN or aCNN given appropriate data (where implicit connectives is either missing or present, respectively).
body_sentences.99: The output D(H) estimates the probability that H comes from the connective-augmented a-CNN rather than i-CNN.

body_sentences.131: 3.3 Component Structures  We have presented our adversarial framework for implicit relation classification.
body_sentences.132: We now discuss the model realization of each component.
body_sentences.133: All components of the framework are parameterized with neural networks.
body_sentences.134: Distinct roles of the modules in the framework lead to different modeling choices.
body_sentences.135: Relation Classification Networks Figure 2 illustrates the structure of the implicit relation network i-CNN.
body_sentences.136: We use a convolutional network as it is a common architectural choice for discourse parsing.
body_sentences.137: The network takes as inputs the word vectors of the tokens in each sentence argument, and maps each argument to intermediate features through a shared convolutional layer.
body_sentences.138: The resulting representations are then concatenated and fed into a max pooling layer to select most salient features as the final representation.
body_sentences.139: The final classifier C is a simple fully-connected layer followed by a softmax classifier.
body_sentences.140: The connective-augmented network a-CNN has a similar structure as i-CNN, wherein implicit connective is appended to the second sentence as input.
body_sentences.141: The key difference from i-CNN is that here we adopt average k-max pooling, which takes the average of the top-k maximum values in each pooling window.
body_sentences.142: The reason is to prevent the network from solely selecting the connective induced features (which are typically the most salient features) which would be the case when using max pooling, but instead force it to also attend to contextual features derived from the arguments.
body_sentences.143: This facilitates more homogeneous output features of the two networks, and thus facilitates feature imitation.
body_sentences.144: In all the experiments we fixed k = 2.
body_sentences.145: Discriminator The discriminator is a binary classifier to identify the correct source of an input feature vector.
body_sentences.146: To make it a strong rival to the feature imitating network (i-CNN), we model the discriminator as a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) enhanced with gated mechanism for efficient information flow (Srivastava et al., 2015; Qin et al., 2016c), as shown in Figure 3.

body_sentences.151: 4.1 Experiment Setup  We use PDTB 2.01, one of the largest manually annotated discourse relation corpus.
body_sentences.152: The dataset contains 16,224 implicit relation instances in total, with three levels of senses: Level-1 Class, Level-2 Type, and Level-3 Subtypes.
body_sentences.153: The 1st level consists of four major relation Classes: COMPARISON, CONTINGENCY, EXPANSION and TEMPORAL.
body_sentences.155: To make extensive comparison with prior work of implicit discourse relation classification, we evaluate on two popular experimental settings: 1) multi-class classification for 2nd-level types (Lin et al., 2009; Ji and Eisenstein, 2015), and 2) oneversus-others binary classifications for 1st-level classes (Pitler et al., 2009).

body_sentences.224: 5 Discussions  We have developed an adversarial neural framework that facilitates an implicit relation network to extract highly discriminative features by mimicking a connective-augmented network.
body_sentences.225: Our method achieved state-of-the-art performance for implicit discourse relation classification.
body_sentences.226: Besides implicit connective examples, our model can naturally exploit enormous explicit connective data to further improve discourse parsing.
body_sentences.227:
The proposed adversarial feature imitation scheme is also generally applicable to other context to incorporate indicative side information
available at training time for enhanced inference.
body_sentences.228: Our framework shares a similar spirit of the iterative knowledge distillation method (Hu et al., 2016a,b) which train a “student” network to mimic the classification behavior of a knowledgeinformed “teacher” network.
body_sentences.229: Our approach encourages imitation on the feature level instead of the final prediction level.
body_sentences.230: This allows our approach to apply to regression tasks, and more interestingly, the context in which the student and teacher networks have different prediction outputs, e.g., performing different tasks, while transferring knowledge between each other can be beneficial.
body_sentences.231: Besides, our adversarial mechanism provides an adaptive metric to measure and drive the imitation procedure.
